channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for MI
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for MI

item.title: Report E-2024070295
item.description:
Report E-2024070295

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-16T09:14:31+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-11
  • City: BYRON CENTER
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent absorbents and containerized it into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070180
item.description:
Report E-2024070180

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: BYRON CENTER
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately five gallons of material released from one (1) 5-gallon metal pail due to a forklift puncture. The released material impacted the concrete terminal floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and recovered the spent absorbents and containerized it along with the damaged pail in one 10-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2024070654
item.description:
Report X-2024070654

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-11T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-27
  • City: FLINT
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: LEAKER WAS IDENTIFIED ON DOOR 4 IN THE UNLOAD, RESPONDER ARRIVED WITH A SPILL TUB, PADS, AND PPE. THE BOX WAS LEAKING, AND PARTIALLY OPEN. IT DIDN'T LOOK LIKE A TYPICAL HOUSEHOLD ITEM SO RESPONDER OPENED THE BOX A BIT MORE AND SAW THE CORROSIVE DIAMOND LABEL. THEN PROCEEDED TO NOTIFY MY SUPERVISOR AND CONTINUE CLEANUP. RESPONDER CALLED THE HAZMAT HELP DESK AND NOTIFIED THEM, PROCESSED IN ETT, TOOK PICTURES OF ALL 6 SIDES OF THE BOX, AND HOLD FOR INSPECITON.

item.title: Report X-2024070369
item.description:
Report X-2024070369

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: OAK PARK
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Federal Express Corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The shipper shipped a box containing three laptops and six tablets, all of which still had their Li-Ion batteries installed, without placing either a Class 9 diamond label or UN3481 Li-Ion battery sticker on the outside of the box. One of the cells in the Li-Ion battery of one of the laptops started generating a current, despite the laptop being powered off. This resulted in a buildup of heat sufficient to melt the malfunctioning battery cell, part of the laptop case, and some of the bubble wrap surrounding the laptop. It also gave off smoke and an unpleasant odor.
